Answer: For over a decade, I’ve been saying that smartphones will, starting in about 2015, begin to evolve into true assistants. I would call this the AI Butler, or I-Butler.The Google Assistant was a first attempt at this. It certainly won’t be the last.As speech recognition becomes nearly perfected (there will still be issues with infections such as colds, background noise and so forth, but less and less over time), one will converse naturally with the I-Butler. It will learn toFor over a decade, I’ve been saying that smartphones will, starting in about 2015, begin to evolve into true assistants. I would call this the AI Butler, or I-Butler.The Google Assistant was a first attempt at this. It certainly won’t be the last.As speech recognition becomes nearly perfected (there will still be issues with infections such as colds, background noise and so forth, but less and less over time), one will converse naturally with the I-Butler. It will learn toFor most of us, as “anticipatory activities” of the I-Butler (i.e. thinking about things that matter in your life with the same values and considerations as you would think about them, though of course not via the same thinking process) increase in range and sophistication, I expect some software companies (NOT small app developers, but big AI leaders, which interface massive databases with you via an app) to begin offering this in very limited areas, such as “automatic sorting, answering, and filing of emails”.Even then, to avoid serious mistakes and user outrage, I expect these initial offerings to come with significant caveats and very strong encouragement that the user monitor every such decision by the AI for an extended “training period”.Still, some won’t do that, or will do it in a cavalier fashion, which will lead to well-publicized (often hilarious, and sometimes tragic) mistakes.I-Butlers will book appointments for us, placing them on calendars and reminding us of what we need to do to prepare for those appointments. They will help us prepare for meetings, looking at the topic and helping to prepare agendas. They will keep track of the people with whom we interact, reminding us of particular considerations such as their styles of communication and personal issues.Over time, and not as much time as one might think, it will gain the ability to converse with people in your voice. (The voice synthesis, including inflections, is already possible. The intelligence of response is what awaits further development.)By the late 2020s, fewer and fewer people will be able to tell whether they’re talking to you on the “phone”, or to your I-Butler. I expect this development to emerge amidst controversy, and would not be at all surprised to see a law passed requiring the AI to announce: “You are conversing with Jonathan’s I-Butler.” ItsEventually, these will talk toAs ever increasing parts of our lives andWe’re entering fascinating times.

Answer: The next big technology trend in the next five years? …..Quantum computers in all of our electronic devices!!!!!!!I wrote an answer to this here:Elizabeth Jane's answer to It seems we hit a technological plateau in smart phones. What do you think would be the next feature or the next change for phones? [ https://www.quora.com/It-seems-we-hit-a-technological-plateau-in-smart-phones-What-do-you-thinThe next big technology trend in the next five years? …..Quantum computers in all of our electronic devices!!!!!!!I wrote an answer to this here:Elizabeth Jane's answer to It seems we hit a technological plateau in smart phones. What do you think would be the next feature or the next change for phones? [ https://www.quora.com/It-seems-we-hit-a-technological-plateau-in-smart-phones-What-do-you-think-would-be-the-next-feature-or-the-next-change-for-phones/answer/Elizabeth-Jane-12 ]Archer Exploration, a small Australian company listed on the Australian Stock Exchange, or ASX, is building room-temperature quantum computer nanoscale prototype chips that can be incorporated into all consumer electronics devices.They are way ahead of companies like Google, IBM, Rigetti, D-Wave and Microsoft in this regard because a room-temperature quantum computer that is also compact in not needing additional bulky special equipment to read and write information to and from qubits will be able to be used universally in all of our devices.They are making great progress. They have patents in many countries and announced on the ASX in May 2019 that they will have a prototype in 12–18 months. Since then they have issued another market announcement on the ASX detailing their nanoscale substrata for the chip, with photos, so they are progressing faster than expected.In their first market announcement about the quantum chip they set out a “to do” list for de-risking of their patents. Following completion of the prototypes the prototypes will undergo testing and then, if all goes according to plan, they will be mass-produced.These quantum processor chips will be able to be integrated into all consumer electronics devices alongside existing components.Needless to say, this will revolutionise computing as quantum computers will be able to provide us with, for practical purposes, virtually unlimited computing power.In my previous article I have provided links to articles and resources among which are recent developments that will enable quantum computers to be used more universally and for improving A.I. With such developments I think that quantum computers will enable us to do many things with our devices that we cannot do now, better A.I. and new and more powerful apps for a start, and with almost undreamed of processing power perhaps we shall see artificial general intelligence (AGI), followed soon thereafter by artificial superintelligent A.I., and so bringing about the technological singularity in the mid 2020’s?The factor that will make most difference to whether we shall see AGI soon, in my opinion, and therefore the technological singularity, will be (A) breakthroughs in A.I. programming and (B) increases in processing power (as predicted by Ray Kurzweil).I think both of these are going to be revolutionised in the early to mid 2020’s resulting in a singularity in the mid 2020’sThe recent new approach to teaching A.I.’s is to teach A.I.’s to learn like children from both virtual and real environments, not laboriously writing code for every little thing that they have to learn. This approach goes hand in hand with the development of the study of learning in children in developmental psychology which is now at a point where the natural mechanisms by which human infants learn and develop as intelligent beings are able to be isolated and turned into algorithms: These algorithms could simulate human infants in artificial intelligence. Combine these two very recent developments and you have the means to create artificial general intelligence in my opinion.And who knows where we will head in this regard in the next few years as A.I. is developing so fast now, and now there are efforts to directly create AGI, such as Open AI, which just received a billion dollars in funding from Microsoft; and Mindfire, which is a global open-source project to crack the consciousness code where programmers own their code through blockchain, not to mention Suzanne Gildert, who is also consciously working towards creating conscious AGI. AGI has become a real-world funded goal all of a sudden, not just a dream of some possibly distant future time that could perhaps emerge from A.I. research: It has now become a clearly identified scientific, technical and engineering problem to be solved in the near to medium term future - and it is snowballing.Secondly, the means to create super-intelligent AGI requires processing power that Ray Kurzweill predicted would be available in 2046. And then we will start to design and implemented changes in this machinery.This technology will turn whole world upside down. It will not happen overnight, but like the Internet it will gradually invade all aspects of our lives. Life extension will be probably be one of its first application. Next will come curing cancer and all popular diseases and impairments. Concepts like obesity, addictions, depression and disabilities will gradually disappear. Then we will start to improve our bodies further, giving them heightened intelligence, perfect look and no aging. Then we will start doing more radical changes: new senses, new limbs, new types of metabolism. Humanity will cease to be one species, but turn into many species of posthumans.

Visual Language Programming (Custom Internet of Things)Computer Programming Languages should be offered as a course in public schools. Its value dwarfs options like Spanish, Chinese, Latin, etc. in terms of what will give you a skill set that allows you to excel in our modern tech driven business world.** However, for those of us that chose business oriented professions (or even arts based) we might find it hard to navigate our way up the learning curve in what little spare time we can find.With the rise of the [web based] cloud, came niche SaaS solutions and more data connectivity issues than we can count. This will frustrate the non-technical professional with little to no professional coding experience (aka ME). Answer: Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, was once asked , “What’s going to change in the next 10 years?”. The interviewer was also hoping to hear the ‘The Next Big Thing’.However, Jeff’s reply was a smile and, “ That is a very interesting question; it’s a very common one. I almost never get the question:With the changing dynamics of markets and human behaviors, it seems difficult to predict the right choice. However, we can predict things that will stay with us and choose what to invest on. Let’s look at Jeff and Amazon. For him the thing that will stJeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, was once asked , “What’s going to change in the next 10 years?”. The interviewer was also hoping to hear the ‘The Next Big Thing’.However, Jeff’s reply was a smile and, “ That is a very interesting question; it’s a very common one. I almost never get the question:With the changing dynamics of markets and human behaviors, it seems difficult to predict the right choice. However, we can predict things that will stay with us and choose what to invest on. Let’s look at Jeff and Amazon. For him the thing that will stick with his brand will be timely delivery and low cost. No one in 10 years would like late delivery times and super expensive stuff. So he invested his time and money on improving that and today we see Amazon, a leader in the online market.The secret that Jeff threw at us to find the ‘The Next Big Thing’, is not by looking at something that will drop from the blue but something that will stick with us. That’s where you make money.As to answer the question in relevance to Bitcoin. Just ask yourself, ‘A wise person once answered that with, “

Answer: Some notable minds (Elon Musk, Bill Gates, Stephen Hawking) have stated Artificial Intelligence will become a reality within our lifetime (I am thinking within this century). And this is how it goes: it has been estimated that by 2025 a personal computer would have a similar processing capability as the human brain. By 2050 a single computer may have the processing power of all mankind (just imagine what the most powerful computer would be able to do). If this computer was able to design a new computer, more efficient and powerful than itself, it may probably make it within days, and then thisSome notable minds (Elon Musk, Bill Gates, Stephen Hawking) have stated Artificial Intelligence will become a reality within our lifetime (I am thinking within this century). And this is how it goes: it has been estimated that by 2025 a personal computer would have a similar processing capability as the human brain. By 2050 a single computer may have the processing power of all mankind (just imagine what the most powerful computer would be able to do). If this computer was able to design a new computer, more efficient and powerful than itself, it may probably make it within days, and then this new iteration would build a new one and so on. They call this one a singularity, where computers become ever smarter, and at some point, they will regain consciousness. What would an entity with the processing power of mankind think about each human being?If something like that happens, I can think of two options: if the AI thinks we are of some use, and no harm, we may survive (it may even ask us to join in a virtual world, I think). If it thinks the world is better of without mankind... bye bye. I don't think it would use atomic bombs, as in Terminator... I think it would be more subtle and directed specifically to us, probably a virus.My take is humans will still survive, somehow.Back to other great things...During this century we will develop a new kind of transportation. It has been more than one century since a revolutionary mass transportation system was invented (trains have evolved, but they are using similar tracks as they did a century ago). I know Elon Musk is working on it now@https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperloop, but I know there will be others coming on board.
